docs.lead_paragraph: Citing his mother's death from cancer, President Clinton drew attention today to efforts to fight the disease through Medicare's coverage of tests to detect breast, cervical and colorectal cancer. Speaking in his weekly radio address, Mr. Clinton highlighted provisions in the balanced budget agreement to extend the availability of mammograms, pap smears and colorectal screening exams. The provisions were part of a budget deal reached in the summer.

headline.main: Clinton Cites Medicare Role In Financing Cancer Tests

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton, citing mother's death from cancer, highlights provisions in balanced budget agreement to extend availability of mammograms, pap smears and colorectal exams through Medicare coverage; mother died of breast cancer in 1994 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH nothing to protect her but a vial of heart medicine, Ruth Kain spent the last year and a half willing herself to stay well. Then, a week before Thanksgiving, she felt a crushing pain in her chest, jaw and left arm so severe that it took her breath away. She was taken to the hospital, where doctors discovered a major blockage in an artery. Mrs. Kain, 64, of Ava, Mo., is one of millions of Americans aged 55 to 64 who find it difficult -- or impossible -- to obtain health insurance. While her pain has gone away, for now at least, her worries have not. Since her husband's retirement and the expiration of his employer-sponsored health insurance in 1995, Mrs. Kain has been unable to find coverage for her heart condition.

headline.main: Not Ready for Medicare, and Uninsured

docs.lead_paragraph: With three business days remaining this year, there is still time for some tidying up of your financial affairs. Here is a list of moves to consider, as compiled by Jan M. Rosen, Edward Wyatt and David J. Morrow. Taxes Add up your losses. If you sold stocks or mutual funds at a gain during the year and are sitting on losses in your portfolio -- in, say, international or Pacific funds that have tanked with the Asian crisis -- a sale before year-end will offset the gain. What is more, if your loss positions exceed your gains, as much as $3,000 of net capital losses can be taken as a deduction against ordinary income. This will also work if you have made no trades but have paper losses you can take.

headline.main: A Last 'To Do List' for the Year

docs.lead_paragraph: Health maintenance organizations are supposed to provide care at a lower cost than traditional insurance. But as Federal programs often do, Medicare has surprised its sponsors by spending more, not less, per person on the 5.9 million elderly and disabled Americans who have joined H.M.O.'s. Congress recently limited the increase in next year's payments to Medicare H.M.O's to 2 to 3 percent, down sharply from 10 percent only two years ago. Some H.M.O.'s reacted by raising prices and ending freebies, upsetting elderly members who often live on tight budgets.

docs.lead_paragraph: INSIDE the sun-drenched angioplasty suite at Bridgeport Hospital, Wanda Belovitch of Stratford rested, chatted with a nurse and organized her belongings to go home. Days earlier, she had begun to have chest pains and shortness of breath and had been rushed to the hospital. Tests revealed severe blockages in her left anterior descending artery and right coronary artery. Not long ago, such findings typically led to coronary bypass surgery. But Mrs. Belovitch was able to opt for less-invasive treatment: an angioplasty, followed by the insertion of a tiny stainless steel coil called a stent to buttress the expanded artery and drastically lower the chances of the artery's closing up again. Bypass surgery would have kept her in the hospital for several days followed by a long recovery; the newer procedure allowed her to go home the following day. For Mrs. Belovitch, a 74-year-old retired accounting clerk for the Internal Revenue Service, the experience seemed nearly miraculous. ''It's really astonishing what they can do,'' she said, adding that she had no concerns about leaving the hospital so soon after her procedure. ''I'm tired but I feel good.''

headline.main: The Hospitals of Tomorrow, Taking Shape Today . . .

docs.abstract: Article describes latest medical advances that are being used in hospitals across Connecticut tempered with need to overhaul costs and procedures as result of constraints put on them by managed care insurance; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: SINCE it incorporated 105 years ago, Norwalk Hospital has been an independent hospital, but its board of directors is now considering an affiliation with Yale-New Haven Hospital, becoming part of what has become one of the dominant health service networks in southwestern and central Connecticut. ''As managed care has become a more significant factor in health care, we've had to consider an alliance to offer the best value,'' said Maura E. Romaine, a spokeswoman for Norwalk. ''The Yale-New Haven network was the most fully developed for our market, Fairfield County, and will allow us to continue to provide personalized and comprehensive services.''

headline.main: . . . With New Networks a Major Factor

docs.lead_paragraph: There's always someone with a great idea in this city, a fresh way of making a buck, making a connection, making a match, making art, making a neighborhood more attractive or making the right people pay. But of all those people spinning wild notions in their heads only a few turn their dreams into reality. Here are some New Yorkers who did and who made a mark in the past year by following one muse or another. SOMETIMES IT PAYS TO FIGHT CITY HALL

headline.main: Some Who Turned Their Dreams Into News

docs.lead_paragraph: ''A kid playing soccer fell and broke his arm,'' said Dr. Michael Weaver, beginning the sort of anecdote that emergency room doctors routinely reel off. ''His mom scoops him up and rushes him here, the nearest hospital. I start an IV to give him pain medication. Then mom runs in and says, 'Stop!' ''She's called her insurance company,'' said Dr. Weaver, 44, chief emergency physician for the St. Luke's-Shawnee Mission group of hospitals here. ''They tell her to take him to a hospital four miles away. Mom's in tears. The kid's in tears. We give him oral pain medication, an ice bag and a splint. Then Mom drives him to the next hospital.

headline.main: Fitting Managed Care Into Emergency Rooms

docs.abstract: St Luke's-Shawnee Mission hospitals in Kansas City, Mo, illustrates the ways managed care is affecting emergency rooms, forcing them to adopt cost-cutting discipline for good or ill and raising complaints from doctors and patients about hassles and disruptions of care; insurers have squeezed their payments to hospitals to the point where there is little, if any, excess to cover nonpaying patients that hospitals are bound by law to serve; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS far as he can recall, Frederick Hartman has never dismissed an employee. In its 65-year history, his company has never had a layoff. And he has never asked anyone to retire. Quite the contrary. When Mary Boyt retired recently -- at the age of 89 -- Mr. Hartman was not at all happy about it.

headline.main: A Company Where Retirement Is a Dirty Word

docs.abstract: Average age of workers at Vita Needle Co, which recruits retirees from other fields, is 73; Frederick Hartman, president, holds older workers are loyal, responsible and eligible for Medicare, eliminating need for company-paid health coverage; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Eileen Guez stood up with a grunt, excused herself and headed for the kitchen. ''I have to light the oven for dinner,'' she explained as she shuffled away, visibly pained. Nearly 10 minutes later she reappeared, explaining her long absence with an embarrassed titter. ''I was striking the wrong end of the match,'' she said, her expression blank. ''Ah, the details.''

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; A Mother With a Harsh Disease Yearns to Feel Whole Again
